statements.name: PROC FCMP
statements.description: Creates, tests, and stores SAS functions, CALL routines, and subroutines.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: reads an input data set into the PROC FCMP step.

arguments.name: ENCRYPT
arguments.description: encodes the source code in a data set.

arguments.name: FLOW
arguments.description: specifies printing a message for each statement in a program as it is executed.

arguments.name: LIBRARY=
arguments.description: links previously compiled libraries.
arguments.help:
LIBRARY=library.dataset
LIBRARY=(library-1.dataset library-2.dataset ... library-n.dataset)
LIBRARY=library.datasetM - library.datasetN

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: specifies that both the LISTSOURCE and LISTPROG options are in effect.

arguments.name: LISTALL
arguments.description: specifies that the LISTCODE, LISTPROG, and LISTSOURCE options are in effect.

arguments.name: LISTCODE
arguments.description: specifies the printing of compiled program code.

arguments.name: LISTFUNCS
arguments.description: lists the prototypes and subroutines for all visible FCMP functions in the SAS listing.

arguments.name: LISTPROG
arguments.description: specifies the printing of compiled programs.

arguments.name: LISTSOURCE
arguments.description: specifies the printing of source code statements.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: creates an output data set.

arguments.name: OUTFILE=
arguments.description: writes referenced functions and the main program to a text file. Programs that have been parsed by PROC FCMP, including macro variables, can be exported.

arguments.name: OUTITEMSTORE=
arguments.description: exports symbols, referenced functions, and the main program to the specified item store. OUTITEMSTORE does not support a fileref. You must use a quoted path.

arguments.name: OUTLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the name of an output data set to which compiled subroutines and functions are written.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: specifies printing the result of each statement in a program as it is executed.

arguments.name: TRACE
arguments.description: specifies printing the results of each operation in each statement in a program as it is executed.

statements.name: ABORT
statements.description: Terminates the current DATA step, job, or SAS session.

statements.name: ARRAY
statements.description: Associates a name with a list of variables and constants.

arguments.name: array-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the array.

arguments.name: dimensions
arguments.description: is a numeric representation of the number of elements in a one-dimensional array or the number of elements in each dimension of a multidimensional array.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variables of the array.

arguments.name: constant
arguments.description: specifies a number or a character string that indicates a fixed value. Enclose character constants in quotation marks.

arguments.name: initial-values
arguments.description: gives initial values for the corresponding elements in the array. You can specify internal values inside parentheses.

arguments.name: /NOSYMBOLS
arguments.description: specifies that an array of numeric or character values be created without the associated element variables. In this case, the only way that you can access elements in the array is by array subscripting.

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Specifies format, label, and length information for variables.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variables that you want to associate with attributes.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in the variable argument.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in the variable argument.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of the variable in the variable argument.

arguments.name: object-reference
arguments.description: specifies the reference name for the object.

arguments.name: object-type
arguments.description: specifies the type of object to declare.

statements.name: DELETEFUNC
statements.description: Causes a function to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option.

arguments.name: function-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of a function to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option.

statements.name: DELETESUBR
statements.description: Causes a subroutine to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option.

arguments.name: subroutine-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of a subroutine to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option.

statements.name: FUNCTION
statements.description: Specifies a subroutine declaration for a routine that returns a value.

arguments.name: function-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the function.

arguments.name: argument
arguments.description: specifies one or more arguments for the function. You specify character arguments by placing a dollar sign ($) after the argument name. In the following example, function myfunct(arg1, arg2 $, arg3, arg4 $); arg1 and arg3 are numeric arguments, and arg2 and arg4 are character arguments.

arguments.name: expression
arguments.description: specifies the value that is returned from the function.

arguments.name: VARARGS
arguments.description: specifies that the function supports a variable number of arguments. If you specify VARARGS, then the last argument in the function must be an array.
specifies that the function returns a character value. If $ is not specified, the function returns a numeric value.

arguments.name: length
arguments.description: specifies the length of a character value.

arguments.name: KIND=
arguments.description: specifies a collection of items that have specific attributes and is limited to 32 characters.

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: specifies a collection of items that have specific attributes and is limited to 32 characters.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 characters, including blanks.

statements.name: LABEL
statements.description: Specifies a label of up to 256 characters.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names the variable that you want to label.

arguments.name: 'label'
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 characters, including blanks.

statements.name: LISTFUNC
statements.description: Causes the source code for a function to be written to the SAS listing.

arguments.name: function-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the function for which source code is written to the SAS listing.

arguments.name: /NODEPENDENTS
arguments.description: specifies that only the functions specified by function-name be returned and not any dependent functions.

statements.name: LISTSUBR
statements.description: Causes the source code for a subroutine to be written to the SAS listing.

arguments.name: subroutine-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the subroutine for which source code is written to the SAS listing.

statements.name: OUTARGS
statements.description: Specifies arguments in an argument list that you want a subroutine to update.

arguments.name: out-argument
arguments.description: specifies arguments from the argument list that you want the subroutine to update.

statements.name: STATIC
statements.description: Retains a variable’s value from a previous call until the variable is reassigned.

arguments.name: variables
arguments.description: specifies variable names, variable lists, or array names whose values you want to retain.

arguments.name: initial-values
arguments.description: specifies an initial value, numeric or character, for one or more of the preceding elements.

statements.name: STRUCT
statements.description: Declares (creates) structure types that are defined in C-Language packages.

arguments.name: structure-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of a structure that is defined in a C-language package and declared in PROC FCMP.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variable that you want to declare as this structure type.

statements.name: SUBROUTINE
statements.description: Declares (creates) an independent computational block of code that you can call using a CALL statement.

arguments.name: subroutine-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of a subroutine.

arguments.name: argument
arguments.description: specifies one or more arguments for the subroutine. Character arguments are specified by placing a dollar sign ($) after the argument name. In the following example, subroutine mysub(arg1, arg2 $, arg3, arg4 $); arg1 and arg3 are numeric arguments, and arg2 and arg4 are character arguments.

arguments.name: OUTARGS
arguments.description: specifies arguments from the argument list that the subroutine should update.

arguments.name: out-argument
arguments.description: specifies arguments from the argument list that you want the subroutine to update.

arguments.name: VARARGS
arguments.description: specifies that the subroutine supports a variable number of arguments. If you specify VARARGS, then the last argument in the subroutine must be an array.

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: specifies a collection of items that have specific attributes and is limited to 32 characters.

arguments.name: KIND=
arguments.description: specifies a collection of items that have specific attributes and is limited to 32 characters.
